body:
Hi, @flamby. Thank you for your attention to mlfinlab.
There is nothing bad that some trades are not used in the latest bar. The nature of the tick/volume/dollar bar generation is sequential. Furthermore, I can't see any applications of reverse order bar generation, because in this case, you start to suffer from look-ahead bias which is extremely undesirable in algorithmic trading.

Hi @proskurin 

Sorry, I have been vague in my fix suggestion.
By reverse order, I don't mean building one bar using ticks in reverse order per se, but build the last bar (let's call it _**b**_) using the last 1000 ticks (in time order), then proceed with the _**b-1**_, and so on. So no lookahead bias.

But a more simpler way would just be to keep it like it is now, but starting with a multiple of the thresholds. That way, the last bar would be complete in the sense that I expressed.

> There is nothing bad that some trades are not used in the latest bar. 

With the current algorithm, if the last bar by any chance is built using only 10 ticks whereas we ask for a threshold of 1000, I do think it's a problem. I don't see how a ML algorithm could not be misled from a `volume` and `cum_buy_volume` perspective, for instance.

Thanks
The algorithm is implemented is such a way that bar won't be generated until threshold condition is met. So it is not possible to have a bar with num_ticks for example 10 when threshold is 1000

> The algorithm is implemented is such a way that bar won't be generated until threshold condition is met. So it is not possible to have a bar with num_ticks for example 10 when threshold is 1000

So why am I having different volume values for my last bar then? (first post example where I compare manually computed with `get_tick_bars`)
Can you try to reproduce my code?
As I can see from your example, the last bar has 1000 ticks which is correct
The point is the volume value discrepancy.

Sure, because if you use [-threshold] means that all ticks till the latest one are used, however latest tick bar was formed at point of time before the latest tick in your data set. That is why volume as different.
Let's have a toy example. Let's say, you have 1000 ticks. The sum of volumes of latest 3 ticks (998, 999, 1000) is 200. However, if you generate tick bars with threshold equal to 3, you latest bar with be generated on tick number 999m, so volume inside of this bar will be different.

I see. My bad. Sorry for that.

Regarding the fact that the algorithm simply drops the last ticks, from a trading perspective, that could be problematic if latest ticks prices drift significantly, would you consider my suggestion of starting the bars creation with a multiple of the threshold then?
The idea of package is to be as close as possible to 'Advances if Financial Machine Learning' book, so this modification will change the behavior of original algorithm and can mislead users
I understand. If by any chance I come up with an implementation, would you consider a pull request integration that add it as a non default option? (christmas spirit ;-)

> I see. My bad. Sorry for that.
> 
> Regarding the fact that the algorithm simply drops the last ticks, from a trading perspective, that could be problematic if latest ticks prices drift significantly, would you consider my suggestion of starting the bars creation with a multiple of the threshold then?

The implementation is built for a research environment and not for a live data feed. It is under those conditions which I believe the implementation will provide the correct sampling.

If you are using this on live data then the ticks being dropped will be a problem but the expectation is that user will need to build a new implementation for a live data feed.

I only see this usefull when you have to oversample the dataset, resampling with different tick starts/ends on the same dataset

With a 1000trades per bar, we can create 999 diferent datasets from standard one just removing the first 999 trades
Yeah, however this logic is valid only for tick bars. It won’t work for volume/dollar

It’s something that can be executed outside of the lib

Maybe something useful should be a function to calculate the last bar volume, with this call we could remove the first trades, and/or include a offset at bar create functions

Hi @proskurin @Jackal08 @rspadim 

I came up with this implementation below. At least, it has no impact on normal tick bar creation behaviour and is very little invasive. Tell me if you agree for a pull request, alter it, or want to push it yourself.

I understand the research-only direction, but I'm afraid more and more like me will want to use your lib for live or paper-trading. In a sense, it's the real validation of research to pass it live data, don't you think ;-) and switching to another lib for live trading leads inevitably to fear of bug or differences of implementation, thus, not reproducing research accurately.

```diff
diff -urN -x '*.pyc' b/mlfinlab/mlfinlab/data_structures/base_bars.py mlfinlab/mlfinlab/data_structures/base_bars.py
--- b/mlfinlab/mlfinlab/data_structures/base_bars.py    2019-12-24 22:32:03.654588745 +0100
+++ mlfinlab/mlfinlab/data_structures/base_bars.py  2019-12-25 15:33:19.427715025 +0100
@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@
     they are included here so as to avoid a complicated nested class structure.
     """

-    def __init__(self, file_path_or_df: Tuple[str, pd.DataFrame], metric: str, batch_size: int = 2e7):
+    def __init__(self, file_path_or_df: Tuple[str, pd.DataFrame], metric: str, batch_size: int = 2e7, live: bool = False, threshold: int = None):
         """
         Constructor

@@ -42,14 +42,27 @@
                                 raw tick data  in the format[date_time, price, volume]
         :param metric: (str) type of imbalance bar to create. Example: dollar_imbalance.
         :param batch_size: (int) Number of rows to read in from the csv, per batch.
+        :param live: (bool) Make sure last ticks are part of the last bar, for live trading
+        :param threshold: (Int) Tick threshold
         """

+        self.threshold = threshold
+
         if isinstance(file_path_or_df, str):
             self.generator_object = pd.read_csv(file_path_or_df, chunksize=batch_size, parse_dates=[0])
             # Read in the first row & assert format
             first_row = pd.read_csv(file_path_or_df, nrows=1)
             self._assert_csv(first_row)
         elif isinstance(file_path_or_df, pd.DataFrame):
+            if live:
+                print("*** Dataframe changes for Live Trading ***")
+                print(f"old shape: {file_path_or_df.shape}")
+                # to make sure latest ticks are part of last bar, we get rid of first ticks
+                # not part of a multiple of threshold from a bar perspective
+                rows = file_path_or_df.shape[0]
+                start = rows % threshold
+                file_path_or_df = file_path_or_df.iloc[start:]
+                print(f"new shape: {file_path_or_df.shape}")
             self.generator_object = _crop_data_frame_in_batches(file_path_or_df, batch_size)
         else:
             raise ValueError('file_path_or_df is neither string(path to a csv file) nor pd.DataFrame')
diff -urN -x '*.pyc' b/mlfinlab/mlfinlab/data_structures/standard_data_structures.py mlfinlab/mlfinlab/data_structures/standard_data_structures.py
--- b/mlfinlab/mlfinlab/data_structures/standard_data_structures.py 2019-12-24 22:32:03.654588745 +0100
+++ mlfinlab/mlfinlab/data_structures/standard_data_structures.py   2019-12-25 15:33:01.587767928 +0100
@@ -34,9 +34,9 @@
     """

     def __init__(self, file_path_or_df: Tuple[str, pd.DataFrame], metric: str, threshold: int = 50000,
-                 batch_size: int = 20000000):
+            batch_size: int = 20000000, live: bool = False):

-        BaseBars.__init__(self, file_path_or_df, metric, batch_size)
+        BaseBars.__init__(self, file_path_or_df, metric, batch_size, live=live, threshold=threshold)

         # Threshold at which to sample
         self.threshold = threshold
@@ -59,7 +59,6 @@

         # Iterate over rows
         list_bars = []
-
         for row in data.values:
             # Set variables
             date_time = row[0]
@@ -139,7 +138,7 @@


 def get_tick_bars(file_path_or_df: Tuple[str, pd.DataFrame], threshold: float = 70000000, batch_size: int = 20000000,
-                  verbose: bool = True, to_csv: bool = False, output_path: str = None):
+        verbose: bool = True, to_csv: bool = False, output_path: str = None, live: bool =False):
     """
     Creates the tick bars: date_time, open, high, low, close, volume, cum_buy_volume, cum_ticks, cum_dollar_value.

@@ -149,9 +148,10 @@
     :param verbose: (bool) Print out batch numbers (True or False)
     :param to_csv: (bool) Save bars to csv after every batch run (True or False)
     :param output_path: (str) Path to csv file, if to_csv is True
+    :param live: (bool) Make sure last ticks are part of the last bar, for live trading
     :return: (pd.DataFrame) Dataframe of volume bars
     """
     bars = StandardBars(file_path_or_df=file_path_or_df, metric='cum_ticks',
-                        threshold=threshold, batch_size=batch_size)
+                        threshold=threshold, batch_size=batch_size, live=live)
     tick_bars = bars.batch_run(verbose=verbose, to_csv=to_csv, output_path=output_path)
     return tick_bars
```
I tested it with several tick threshold, and it seems to do the job.

Thanks!

I don’t see why the last bar not complete is a problem.
You can “solve this” at model including a 0/1 variable reporting if bar is complete, the most important variable can’t be this variable. Being the most important variable indicate a bad model for sure or some kind of look ahead or overfitting

About realtime i see as an improvement, we have a historical database and we want to include/remove/change a specific tick, the realtime lib should execute this function fast, and call all indicator functions and after this report that everything is ok

A Next step should be run this in a buck of trades instead of one by one

That’s what a realtime lib should do

A realtime lib should have something like

Init
New tick
Deinit

Where newtick function should be called by a state machine running the marketdata
In the same framework we should have a “create indicator”/“remove indicator” to include others indicators without duplicating, this run on the same state machine of the marketdata

The next step should be order sending and algorithmic trading plataform

See that it is not a problem of this lib, but a improvement, instead of “read all dataset and output indicators(features)” you call a function to “with new data, calculate what should be the new features without loosing time with last calculated values”
